elements.content: Reactions between Cd(NO3)2·6H2O and N,N‘-bis(3-pyridyl)urea (3bpu)/N,N‘-bis(4-pyridyl)urea (4bpu) with a 1:2 metal:ligand ratio under various solvent systems (polar/nonpolar) afforded four discrete coordination complexes, namely, [{(H2O)2Cd(3bpu)4}·(NO3)2·2H2O·X] 1, [{(H2O)2Cd(3bpu)4}·(NO3)2] 3, [{(H2O)2Cd(3bpu)4}·(NO3)2·2H2O·p-xylene] 4 , [{(H2O)2 (NO3)2Cd(μ-4bpu)2}] 8, and four coordination polymers, namely, [{(H2O)3(NO3)Cd(μ-3bpu)}·(NO3)·H2O·1/2o-xylene] n 2, [{(H2O)3(NO3)Cd(μ-3bpu)}·(NO3)·X] n 5, [{(NO3)2Cd(μ-3bpu)2}] n 6, [{(H2O)(NO3)Cd(μ-4bpu)2}·(NO3)·EtOH·nitrobenzene] n 7, which were mainly characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffractometry. The effect of solvents, conformational flexibility, and positional isomerism of the ligands on the various isomerisms (supramolecular isomerism and polymorphism) is discussed.

The effect of solvents, conformational flexibility, and positional isomerism of the ligands on the various isomerisms (supramolecular isomerism and polymorphism) is discussed.

elements.content: Supramolecular isomerism, a phenomenon wherein various supramolecular structures are obtained from an identical building block, is an important subject matter in the area of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering. Its importance becomes obvious when one considers the fact that bulk properties of solids depend upon their supramolecular structures (crystal structures). In true supramolecular isomerism, the building blocks and all the other components must be identical. However, to satisfy the packing, solvent (guest) molecules are often included in the crystal lattice of the coordination polymers, thereby making it difficult to obtain true supramolecular isomers. Thus, the coordination polymers having different solvent content (nature, stoichiometry, etc.) displaying different supramolecular structures are known as pseudo-supramolecular isomers, which is closely related to pseudo-polymorphs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Supramolecular isomerism, a phenomenon wherein various supramolecular structures are obtained from an identical building block, is an important subject matter in the area of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering. Its importance becomes obvious when one considers the fact that bulk properties of solids depend upon their supramolecular structures (crystal structures). In true supramolecular isomerism, the building blocks and all the other components must be identical. However, to satisfy the packing, solvent (guest) molecules are often included in the crystal lattice of the coordination polymers, thereby making it difficult to obtain true supramolecular isomers. Thus, the coordination polymers having different solvent content (nature, stoichiometry, etc.) displaying different supramolecular structures are known as pseudo-supramolecular isomers, which is closely related to pseudo-polymorphs.

elements.content: Examples of both true and pseudo-supramolecular isomers have been reported by various groups thus far. Chen's group has reported intriguing supramolecular isomers derived from imidazole- and triazole-based ligands. Formation of hexagon and zigzag chain derived from benzene dicarboxylic acid based ligands and a novel 3D network of [Zn(nicotinate)2] n demonstrated by Zaworotko's group9 are some of the key examples of pseudo-supramolecular isomers, wherein the template effect of the solvent plays a crucial role. A rare example of coordination polymer polymorph derived from pyrazine and Cd(NO3)2 was reported by Champness's group10a recently. The same group has also reported supramolecular isomerism in coordination polymers derived from CuSCN and triazine derivative. Examples of various types of supramolecular isomers have also been reported.

Chen's group has reported intriguing supramolecular isomers derived from imidazole- and triazole-based ligands. Formation of hexagon and zigzag chain derived from benzene dicarboxylic acid based ligands and a novel 3D network of [Zn(nicotinate)2] n  demonstrated by Zaworotko's group9 are some of the key examples of pseudo-supramolecular isomers, wherein the template effect of the solvent plays a crucial role. A rare example of coordination polymer polymorph derived from pyrazine and Cd(NO3)2 was reported by Champness's group10a recently. The same group has also reported supramolecular isomerism in coordination polymers derived from CuSCN and triazine derivative. Examples of various types of supramolecular isomers have also been reported.

elements.content: These studies clearly demonstrate how interesting and important the supramolecular isomerism is in the context of crystal engineering. It represents a major challenge in the design of molecular selfassembly with predictable supramolecular structures and properties. Thus, it is important to study supramolecular isomerism in various systems in order to gain better insight so that it can perhaps be controlled to achieve the desired supramolecular structure.

elements.content: As a part of our on going research program in generating intriguing supramolecular architectures in coordination polymers12 and organic−inorganic hybrid solids, we have recently introduced two new ligands14 derived from hydrogen-bond-functionalized bis-pyridyl urea derivatives, namely, N,N‘-bis(3-pyridyl)urea (3bpu) and N,N‘-bis(4-pyridyl)urea (4bpu). Although 3bpu can adopt different ligating topologies depending on three plausible conformations, namely, syn−syn, anti−anti, and syn−anti arising because of the Caromatic−Nurea bond rotation, its positional isomer 4bpu can display only nearly linear ligating topology because of the symmetric positioning of the pyridyl N atoms at the para position (Scheme ). Recently we have shown that these two ligands can generate supramolecular structures as diverse as diamondoid and 2D square grid network derived from Zn(II) tetrahedral node.

Although 3bpu can adopt different ligating topologies depending on three plausible conformations, namely, syn-syn, anti-anti, and syn-anti arising because of the Caromatic-Nurea bond rotation, its positional isomer 4bpu can display only nearly linear ligating topology because of the symmetric positioning of the pyridyl N atoms at the para position (Scheme ). Recently we have shown that these two ligands can generate supramolecular structures as diverse as diamondoid and 2D square grid network derived from Zn(II) tetrahedral node.

In this contribution, the effect of solvent on the molecular and supramolecular structures, and isomerisms of coordination complexes and coordination polymers derived from conformationally flexible and hydrogen-bond-functionalized ligand 3bpu and Cd(NO3)2 have been investigated. Conformationally flexible ligating topologies of 3bpu and well-demonstrated structural diversities provided by Cd(NO3)2 species in coordination polymers16 make it a particularly suitable system to study structural diversities as a function of crystallizing solvents, conformation-dependent ligating topologies of 3bpu, and structurally flexible Cd(NO3)2 species. The effect of positional isomerism on the supramolecular structures is also studied in coordination polymer and coordination complex using 4bpu, which is a positional isomer of 3bpu. For this purpose, we reacted 3bpu/ 4bpu with Cd(NO3)2·6H2O in a 2:1 molar ratio in various solvent combinations at ambient conditions. The isolated crystalline products were subjected to single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies along with other physicochemical studies.
elements.clean_text: In this contribution, the effect of solvent on the molecular and supramolecular structures, and isomerisms of coordination complexes and coordination polymers derived from conformationally flexible and hydrogen-bond-functionalized ligand 3bpu and Cd(NO3)2 have been investigated. Conformationally flexible ligating topologies of 3bpu and well-demonstrated structural diversities provided by Cd(NO3)2 species in coordination polymers16 make it a particularly suitable system to study structural diversities as a function of crystallizing solvents, conformation-dependent ligating topologies of 3bpu, and structurally flexible Cd(NO3)2 species. The effect of positional isomerism on the supramolecular structures is also studied in coordination polymer and coordination complex using 4bpu, which is a positional isomer of 3bpu. For this purpose, we reacted 3bpu/ 4bpu with Cd(NO3)2⋅6H2O in a 2:1 molar ratio in various solvent combinations at ambient conditions. The isolated crystalline products were subjected to single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies along with other physicochemical studies.

elements.content: Synthesis. The bipyridyl ligand was dissolved in MeOH or EtOH followed by addition of a specified volume of cosolvents (see Experimental Section). A MeOH or EtOH solution of the metal salt Cd(NO3)2·6H2O was then carefully layered on the ligand solution and kept at ambient condition for approximately 1 week. Single crystals thus obtained were subjected to various physicochemical studies including single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Crystallographic data are given in Table and hydrogen-bonding parameters are given in Table S1 in the Supporting Information. Crystalline phase purity of all the compounds was investigated by comparing the experimental XRPD and the simulated pattern obtained from the single-crystal data (see the Supporting Information). It is important to note that XRPD patterns of 1, 2, 5, and 7 are less crystalline in nature, which could be due to the disordered solvents and counteranion (in 7) present in these crystals. However, the major peaks in these cases do match well with the corresponding simulated patterns, indicating reasonable crystalline phase purity. XRPDs of the rest of compounds do match well with that of the corresponding simulated patterns.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Synthesis. The bipyridyl ligand was dissolved in MeOH or EtOH followed by addition of a specified volume of cosolvents  (see Experimental Section). A MeOH or EtOH solution of the metal salt Cd(NO3)2⋅6H2O was then carefully layered on the ligand solution and kept at ambient condition for approximately 1 week. Single crystals thus obtained were subjected to various physicochemical studies including single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Crystallographic data are given in Table  and hydrogen-bonding parameters are given in Table S1 in the Supporting Information. Crystalline phase purity of all the compounds was investigated by comparing the experimental XRPD and the simulated pattern obtained from the single-crystal data (see the Supporting Information). It is important to note that XRPD patterns of 1, 2, 5, and 7 are less crystalline in nature, which could be due to the disordered solvents and counteranion (in 7) present in these crystals. However, the major peaks in these cases do match well with the corresponding simulated patterns, indicating reasonable crystalline phase purity. XRPDs of the rest of compounds do match well with that of the corresponding simulated patterns.

Crystal Structures. [{(H 2 O) 2 Cd(3bpu) 4 }·(NO 3 ) 2 ·2H 2 O·X] 1. Crystals of 1 belong to the centrosymmetric triclinic space group P1̄. The asymmetric unit contains one metal center Cd(II) located on a center of symmetry, two 3bpu ligands, one water, both coordinated to the metal center, one nitrate counteranion, and one water as solvate and some unaccounted electron densities (1.12−6.95 e/Å3) presumably coming from disordered solvents. The metal center displays a slightly distorted octahedral geometry (∠N−Cd−N = 87.2(1)−92.8(1)°; ∠O−Cd−O = 180.0°); the equatorial positions are occupied by the N atoms of the 3bpu ligands and the apical positions are coordinated by the water molecules. The bipyridyl ligands are not involved in extended coordination resulting in the formation of a coordination complex. Both the crystallographically independent 3bpu ligands display anti−anti conformation with similar molecular nonplanarity, which is evident from various dihedral angles of 2.0−31.7° (pyridyl−urea) and 31.2−37.1° (pyridyl−pyridyl). The nitrate counteranions are found to be trapped between the 3bpu arms of the complex via N−H···O hydrogen bonding (N···O = 2.855(3)−3.134(3) Å; ∠N−H···O = 160.0−176.0°] involving the urea backbone of the ligands. In the crystal structure, the solvate water forms various hydrogen bonding with the nitrate counteranion via O−H···O interactions (2.926(5)−3.1965(5) ∠O−H···O = 148.0(5)−155.0(5)°). Interestingly, the uncoordinated pyridyl N atoms of the 3bpu ligands are free from any hydrogen-bonding interactions. The complexes are packed along a-axis in such a fashion that a channel type architecture is formed, within which the disordered solvates are located (Figure ). The SQUEEZE calculations17 show the presence of 75 e/unit cell, which means ∼38 e/asymmetric unit. This may be attributed to one MeOH and two water molecules (calcd 38 e) per asymmetric unit.

elements.content: [{(H 2 O) 3 (NO 3 )C( μ -3bpu)}·(NO 3 )·H 2 O·1/2o-xylene] n 2. Crystals of 2 belong to the centrosymmetric monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit contains one pyridyl ligand 3bpu, three water, and one nitrate, all coordinated to the metal center Cd(II), one nitrate as counteranion, one water as solvate, and five electron density peaks (located around a center of symmetry). This fragment was refined as half of the statistically disordered o-xylene located around the center of symmetry. SQUEEZE calculations17 without taking the contribution of this fragment show the presence of 108 e/unit cell, i.e., 27 e/asymmetric unit, which is quite close to the number of electron expected for half o-xylene (29 e). In the crystal structure, the metal center displays a slightly distorted octahedral geometry (∠O−Cd−O = 86.2(1)−94.8(1)°; ∠N−Cd−N = 173.2(1)°) wherein the equatorial positions are occupied by the O atoms of three water molecules and one nitrate and the apical positions are coordinated by the N atoms of the pyridyl ligand 3bpu. The bipyridyl ligand adopts a syn−syn conformation with significant molecular nonplanarity, which is evident from the corresponding dihedral angles of 20.3−22.0 and 3.2° involving pyridyl−urea and pyridyl−pyridyl planes respectively. The pyridyl ligand 3bpu forms extended coordination with the adjacent metal centers resulting in the formation of a 1D zigzag coordination polymer propagating along the 21 screw axis. The 1D zigzag polymeric chains are further packed in parallel fashion in such a way that open channel type architecture is formed (Figure ). The statistically disordered o-xylenes are located in such channels. Because of inconsistent solvent loss, TGA of 2 could not be performed.

elements.content: The solvate water molecule is found to be hydrogen bonded with the urea carbonyl and coordinated water molecules via O−H···O interactions (O···O = 2.751(4)−3.014(5) Å; ∠O−H···O = 144.0(5)−171.0(7)°). On the other hand, the nitrate counteranion acts as a bridge between the adjacent 1D chain via hydrogen-bonding interactions involving the urea backbone (N···O = 2.808(4)−2.944(4) Å; ∠N−H···O = 166.2−171.0°) and coordinated water molecules (O···O = 2.805(4)−3.039(4) Å; ∠O−H···O = 124.0(5)−161.0(5)°) of the neighboring chains. The coordinated nitrate, on the other hand, is found to form hydrogen-bonding interactions with the coordinated water molecules of the neighboring chain and the solvate water molecule (O···O = 2.757(4)−2.967(4) Å; ∠O−H···O = 154.0(7)−174.0(6)°).

elements.content: [{(H 2 O) 2 Cd(3bpu) 4 }·(NO 3 ) 2 ] 3. Crystals of 3 belong to the centrosymmetic monoclinic space group C2/c. The asymmetric unit contains one metal center Cd(II) located on a center of symmetry and coordinated by two 3pbu ligands and one water molecule and a nitrate counteranion. No solvate is present in the crystal structure. The metal center displays a slightly distorted octahedral geometry (∠N−Cd−N = 85.9(1)−94.0(1)°; ∠O−Cd−O = 180.0(1)°); the equatorial positions are coordinated by the 3bpu ligands, and the axial positions are occupied by the water molecules. Absence of extended coordination by the pyridyl ligands results in the formation of a coordination complex.

elements.content: The crystallographically independent 3bpu ligands display syn−anti and syn−syn conformation of which the former displays more nonplanar geometry than the latter, which is evident from the various dihedral angles of 6.8−51.7° (pyridyl−urea), 54.5° (pyridyl−pyridyl), 10.6−27.6° (pyridyl−urea), and 17.0° (pyridyl−pyridyl), respectively. The urea backbone of the crystallographically independent 3bpu ligands forms hydrogen-bonding interactions with the nitrate counteranion via N−H···O interactions (N···O = 2.864(3)−3.042(3) Å; ∠N−H···O = 149.8−176.6°) resulting in the formation of a 1D hydrogen-bonded array of the coordination complexes bridged by the nitrate counteranion. Such arrays are further packed in parallel fashion via O−H···N interactions (O···N = 2.807(3)−2.820(3) Å; ∠O−H···N = 170.0(3)−173.2°) involving the free pyridyl N atoms and coordinated water molecules of the neighboring arrays, resulting in the formation of a tightly packed 3D lattice and leaving no room for solvate occlusion (Figure ).

elements.content: Two crystallogrphically independent 3bpu ligands adopts two different conformations namely anti−anti and syn−anti; the former, being more planar than the latter, revealed from the various dihedral angles of 10.4−15.8° (pyridyl−urea), 6.6° (pyridyl−pyridyl) and 13.3−22.3° (pyridyl−urea), 17.8° (pyridyl−pyridyl), respectively. The counteranion nitrate is found to be interacting with the urea moieties of the 3bpu ligands of the complex via N−H···O hydrogen bonding (N···O = 2.877(4)−3.022(4) Å; ∠N−H···O = 148.0−167.4°). The coordination complexes form 1D hydrogen-bonded array along the b-direction via O−H···N interactions involving the coordinated water molecule and the free pyridyl N atom of the neighboring complexes (O···N = 2.775(5) Å; ∠O−H···N = 165.0(5)°). Such 1D arrays are packed in a parallel fashion and stabilized further by hydrogen-bonding interactions with the solvate water molecules; the solvate water is found to form hydrogen-bonding interactions of the type O−H···N (O···N = 2.833(5) Å; ∠O−H···N = 173.0(6)°) with one of the free pyridyl N atoms of the 3bpu ligands, O−H···O (O···O = 2.699(4) Å; ∠O−H···O = 171.0(6)°) with coordinated water molecule and O−H···O (O···O = 2.899(4) Å; ∠O−H···O = 168.0(5)°) with the nitrate counteranion. Such packing of a 1D array creates voids within which the p-xylene solvates are located (Figure ).

elements.content: [{(H 2 O) 3 (NO 3 )Cd( μ -3bpu)}.(NO 3 ).X] n 5. Crystals of 5 belongs to the centrosymmetric orthorhombic space group Pbcn. The asymmetric unit is comprised of one 3bpu, three water molecules, one nitrate, all coordinated to the metal center Cd(II), one nitrate as counteranion, and some disordered electron density peaks (1.27−1.97 e/Å3) that could not be accounted for. In the final cycle of refinement, the unaccounted electron densities are squeezed out17 and only the ordered components are refined. The metal center displays hepta-coordinated and slightly distorted octahedral geometry (∠O−Cd−O = 73.0(2)−83.2(2)°; ∠N−Cd−N = 177.9(2)°); the apical positions are occupied by the N atoms of the 3bpu ligands and the equatorial positions are coordinated by the three water molecules and the nitrate counteranion, which coordinates to the metal center in a chelate fashion resulting in hepta-coordination.

elements.content: The ligand 3bpu adopts a syn−syn conformation and its molecular geometry is found to be reasonably planar displaying pyridyl−urea and pyridyl−pyridyl dihedral angles of 7.3−9.0 and 2.6°, respectively. As a result of the extended coordination of the pyridyl ligands to the adjacent metal center, a zigzag coordination polymer is formed. The chains are further packed in a parallel fashion along the a−b plane in such a manner that an open channel type of architecture is formed. The channel space is filled with the disordered guest molecules (Figure ). Squeeze calculations indicate the presence of 184 e/unit cell, meaning 23 e/asymmetric unit. This may be attributed to one EtOH (calcd 26e) per monomer unit. Because of fast desolvation of the crystals, TGA of 5 could not be performed.

elements.content: [{(NO 3 ) 2 Cd( μ -3bpu) 2 }] n 6. Crystals of 6 belong to the centrosymmetric monoclinic space group P21/n. The asymmetric unit is comprised of one Cd(II) metal center coordinated by one 3bpu ligand and nitrate counteranion. The metal center is found to be on a center of symmetry; as a result, it displays a slightly distorted octahedral geometry, wherein the equatorial positions are occupied by the pyridyl N atoms of the ligands and the apical positions are coordinated by the O atoms of the nitrate counteranion (∠N−Cd−N = 87.5(1)−92.4(1)°; ∠O−Cd−O = 180.0(1)°). The 3bpu ligand adopts a syn − syn conformation and its molecular geometry is found to be significantly distorted displaying pyridyl−pyridyl and urea−pyridyl angles in the ranges of 17.2−18.4 and 33.5°, respectively. Because of the extended coordination of the pyridyl ligand 3bpu in the equatorial plane of the octahedral metal center, a 2D corrugated sheet architecture is formed wherein the metal centers form slightly distorted rhombic array with Cd−Cd distance of 9.209 Å and ∠Cd−Cd−Cd = 67.5−112.4°. However, the space within the grid of the 2D sheet is blocked by the linker ligands due to its syn−syn conformation. The corrugated sheets are further packed along the diagonal of a−c plane further stabilized by N−H···O hydrogen bonding involving the urea backbone and coordinated nitrate counteranion (N···O = 2.861(4)−3.116(4) Å; ∠N−H···O = 123.2−137.9°) (Figure ).

elements.content: [{(H 2 O)(NO 3 )Cd( μ -4bpu) 2 }·(NO 3 )·EtOH·nitrobenzene] n 7. Crystals of 7 belong to the noncentrosymmetric orthorhombic space group Fdd2. The asymmetric unit is comprised of one Cd(II) metal center, two crystallographically independent ligands 4bpu coordinated to the metal center in trans fashion, one water and one nitrate, both coordinated to the metal center, one disordered nitrate counteranion and one EtOH and one nitrobenzene as solvates. The molecular geometry of both the independent 4bpu ligands is found to be significantly nonplanar, displaying pyridyl−pyridyl and urea−pyridyl dihedral angles in the ranges of 49.5−50.9 and 15.9−35.1°, respectively.

The crystal structure can best be described as a coordination polymer having 2D grid architecture arising due to the extended coordination of the pyridyl ligands in the equatorial plane of the octahedral coordination geometry of the metal center. 3-fold interpenetration of the grid is observed in the crystal structure presumably to prevent the collapse of the lattice having significantly large grid dimension of 1.15 × 1.05 nm (Figure ).

elements.content: [{(H 2 O) 2 (NO 3 ) 2 Cd( μ -4bpu) 2 }] 8. Crystals of 8 belong to the centrosymmetric triclinic space group P1̄. The asymmetric unit is comprised of a metal center Cd(II) sitting on a center of symmetry and coordinated by one 4bpu ligand, one nitrate, and one water. In the crystal structure, the metal center displays a slightly distorted octahedral geometry (∠O−Cd−O = 83.3(1)−96.7(1)°; ∠N−Cd−N = 180.0°); the equatorial positions are occupied by the O atoms of nitrate and water, whereas the apical positions are occupied by the N atoms of the 4bpu ligand. Absence of extended coordination by the pyridyl ligands results in the formation of a coordination complex. The complexes are centrosymmetrically arranged via N−H···O interactions involving the urea moiety and coordinated nitrate (N···O = 2.905(6)−2.949(6) Å; ∠N−H···O = 166.5−171.4°), resulting in the formation of 1D array. Such 1D arrays are further packed in 3D via hydrogen-bonding interactions involving coordinated water, pyridyl N atoms, and coordinated nitrate of the neighboring arrays (N···O = 2.712(5) Å; ∠N−H···O = 176.0°; O···O = 2.827(6) Å; ∠O−H···O = 174.0(5)°) (Figure ).

elements.content: FT-IR Analysis. CO stretching and urea N−H bending FT-IR bands and the type of hydrogen-bonding interactions involving these functionalities as observed in the corresponding crystal structures of the compounds studied here as well as of the solvent-free ligands14 are listed in Table .
elements.clean_text: FT-IR Analysis. CO stretching and urea N-H bending FT-IR bands and the type of hydrogen-bonding interactions involving these functionalities as observed in the corresponding crystal structures of the compounds studied here as well as of the solvent-free ligands14 are listed in Table .

elements.content:
FT-IR Bands of the Compounds1−8, 3bpu and 4bpu

compd CO stretching H−bonding bending N−H H−bonding 1 1708 O−H···O & free 1590 N−H···O 2 1709 O−H···O 1617 N−H···O 3 1710 free 1614 N−H···O 4 1713 free 1615 N−H···O 5 1722 free 1590 N−H···O 6 1716 free 1587 N−H···O 7 1736 free 1596 N−H···O 8 1734 free 1598 N−H···O 3bpu 1714 free 1631 N−H···N 4bpu 1740 free 1639 N−H···N

It is clear from Table that the ligands 3bpu and 4bpu in the corresponding solvent-free crystal structures14 do not display any hydrogen bonding involving the CO functionality. Thus, the CO stretching band in the range of 1710−1722 cm-1 for the compounds 3−6 correspond well with that obtained for 3bpu, whereas slightly high-energy shift of the corresponding bands in the range of 1708−1709 cm-1 for the compounds 1 and 2 could be due to its participation in hydrogen bonding. However, the differences of the corresponding bands in these two cases are not significant considering the probable standard deviation, and therefore, the hydrogen-bonding nature of CO is not so apparent from the IR data. Similarly, the CO stretching bands in 7 and 8 also correspond well with that obtained for 4bpu (Table ). It is interesting to note that in both the free ligands 3bpu and 4bpu, the urea N−H is involved in hydrogen bonding of the type N−H···N involving the free pyridyl N atom and the corresponding N−H bending bands appear at 1631 and 1639 cm-1, respectively. However, the urea functionality displays hydrogen bonding of the type N−H···O in all the structure studied here, and the corresponding FT-IR bands appear in the range of 1587−1617 cm-1. The high energy shift could be due to the stronger hydrogen bonding of the type N−H···O compared to N−H···N hydrogen bonding observed in the free ligands.

However, the urea functionality displays hydrogen bonding of the type N-H⋅⋅⋅O in all the structure studied here, and the corresponding FT-IR bands appear in the range of 1587-1617 cm-1. The high energy shift could be due to the stronger hydrogen bonding of the type N-H⋅⋅⋅O compared to N-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonding observed in the free ligands.

The most important conclusion that can be drawn from the data in Table is that the TG data corroborate well with the calculated values obtained from the single-crystal X-ray data. Thus, the assignment of disordered H2O and MeOH present as lattice included solvates in 1 on the basis of SQUEEZE calculations is further supported by TG data. In all cases, the release of both the coordinated and lattice included solvents from the crystal lattice occurred in an overlapping manner within the peak temperature range of 76.4−198.8 °C. The complete collapse of the frameworks occurred within the peak temperature range of 198.8−325.3 °C while releasing the bipyridyl ligands in multistep processes.

It is clear from the Table that the solvent system plays an important role over the nature of the final product. It seems that although polar solvents encourage coordination polymers (entries 5−7, Table ), the less polar one favors formation of coordination complexes (entries 1, 3, 4, and 8, Table ) except in the case of 3bpu in MeOH/o-xylene (entry 2, Table ), wherein both coordination complex 1 and coordination polymer 2 are formed in the single pot. Careful analyses of the crystal structures of 1, 3, and 4 reveal some interesting features that are enlisted in Table .

Structural Parameters of the Coordination Complexes1, 3, and 4

conformation of 3bpu dihedral angles(°) compd coordination sphere conformation pyridyl−pyridyl urea−pyridyl lattice included solvents space group 1 [{(H2O)2Cd(3bpu)4}·(NO3)2] anti−anti 31.2 2.0, 31.0 H2O P1̄ anti−anti 37.1 5.6, 31.7 3 [{(H2O)2Cd(3bpu)4}·(NO3)2] syn−anti 54.5 6.8, 51.7 Nil C2/c syn−syn 17.0 10.6, 27.6 4 [{(H2O)2Cd(3bpu)4}·(NO3)2] anti−anti 6.6 10.4, 15.8 MeOH/ P1̄ syn−syn 17.8 13.3, 22.3 o-xylene

It is clear that compounds 1, 3, and 4 are coordination complexes and show identical coordination sphere [{(H2O)2Cd(3bpu)4}·(NO3)2], although they differ in the nature and content of the lattice included solvents (guests); whereas 3 is free from any lattice included solvent, 1 and 4 show the presence of H2O and H2O/p-xylene, respectively. Although the metal center Cd(II) in these complexes displays a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry, the ligand 3bpu adopts different conformations in these complexes and its molecular geometry is quite nonplanar in these complexes as evident from the corresponding dihedral angles (Table ). Although solvent containing complexes 1 and 4 display identical triclinic space group P1̄, their overall supramolecular structures (crystal structures) differ significantly from each other. Although the coordination complex moiety in 1 packs loosely, resulting in the formation of a porous architecture within which the guests (H2O) are located, 4 displays a more tightly packed architecture that encapsulates the guest molecules (H2O/p-xylene) in a cagelike environment (Figures and ). The differences in packing of 1 and 4 must be arising because of the differences in ligand conformation and hydrogen bonding presumably influenced by the crystallization solvents and lattice included solvates (see crystal structure description). The solvent free complex 3, on the other hand, crystallizes in a different crystal system (monoclinic) with a C2/c space group displaying a tightly packed arrangement leaving no room for guest occlusion (Figure ). Thus, these complexes fall in the category of pseudo-supramolecular isomers. It is interesting to note that ML4 type of complexes involving transition metal and bis-pyridyl ligands are quite rare. In fact, a CSD (5.28, Nov. 2006) search with a fragment containing any transition metal atom coordinated to four pyridyl moieties (having 2 and 6 positions attached to hydrogens) gave 616 hits, out of which only 5 are ML4 type of complexes where L is a bis-pyridyl moiety (REFCODE:  ABOWOE, CEGYIX, FIFZAW, HATMOF, and TETRUF). However, none of these examples displays any supramolecular isomerism.

elements.content:
Structural features of the coordination polymers 2 and 5−7 as revealed from their crystal structures are enlisted in Table .

It may be noted that the coordination spheres and ligand conformation in 2 and 5 are identical, although the details of the molecular geometry of the ligand, space group, and lattice included solvents vary in these structures. However, the overall supramolecular architectures are remarkably similar (Figure and ). Therefore, these two coordination complexes may be categorized as examples of pseudo-polymorphs of coordination polymers. Examples of polymorphic coordination polymer has recently been reported by Champness's group. Coordination polymers 6 and 7 are derived from positionally isomeric ligand 3bpu and 4bpu, respectively, from identical crystallizing solvent systems, namely, EtOH/nitrobenzene. Interestingly, 6 crystallizes without any lattice included solvent, whereas 7 occludes both EtOH and nitrobenzene in its crystal structure. The coordination spheres of the monomeric building block in these two coordination polymers are similar though not identical. It is interesting to note that both the coordination polymers form a 2D gridlike architecture, resulting from a 1:2 metal:ligand ratio. However, because of the syn−syn conformation of 3bpu in 6, the space within the grid is not available for guest occlusion and, as a result, 6 crystallizes out without any lattice included solvent (Figure ). On the other hand, the positional isomer 4bpu has only linear ligating topology by virtue of the symmetrical positioning of the pyridyl N at the para position, resulting in the formation of significantly large grid (1.15 × 1.05 nm2) architecture in 7, which is prevented from collapsing by 3-fold interpenetration (Figure ). It is interesting to note that the discrete coordination complex 8 derived from 4bpu is an ML2 type of complex, unlike the ML4 type complexes 1, 3, and 4 derived from 3bpu. Because of urea−nitrate hydrogen bonding in 8, the complex is arranged in a centrosymmetric array (Figure ), which is further tightly packed and reinforced by N−H···O hydrogen bonding involving pyridyl N and coordinated water molecules, leaving no room for guest occlusion.

By judiciously choosing hydrogen-bond-functionalized, conformationally flexible bispyridyl urea ligands 3bpu and its structural isomer 4bpu in combination with a flexible metal node Cd(NO3)2, it has been demonstrated that solvents play an important role in determining the final products (discrete complex or coordination polymers) and their supramolecular architectures. It seems that less polar templates (toluene, o-, m-, and p-xylene) tend to induce the formation of coordination complexes (1, 3, 4, and 8), whereas more polar templates (nitrobenzene, methylsalicylate) display the formation of coordination polymers (2 and 5−7) with only one exception wherein the less polar template o-xylene gives rise to both coordination polymer (2) and coordination complex (1) in the same pot. Atthough 1, 3, and 4 are coordination complexes displaying pseudo-supramolecular isomerism due to different ligand conformation and solvate contents, the coordination polymers 2 and 5 are best described as pseudo-polymorphs in coordination polymer displaying remarkably similar supramolecular architectures despite having identical coordination spheres and ligand conformation (syn−syn). The effect of positional isomerism of 3bpu and 4bpu can be seen in the coordination polymers 6 and 7, wherein both the polymers display near identical coordination sphere having grid type of architectures. Although the space within the grid is blocked because of syn−syn conformation of 3bpu in 6, 3-fold interpenetration is observed in 7 presumably to prevent the collapse of the large grid. This contribution clearly demonstrates how important the role of solvents, conformational flexibility, and positional isomerism of the hydrogen-bond-functionalized ligands is in determining the final products and various isomerisms of the coordinative metal−organic systems.
elements.clean_text:
Summary

By judiciously choosing hydrogen-bond-functionalized, conformationally flexible bispyridyl urea ligands 3bpu and its structural isomer 4bpu in combination with a flexible metal node Cd(NO3)2, it has been demonstrated that solvents play an important role in determining the final products (discrete complex or coordination polymers) and their supramolecular architectures. It seems that less polar templates (toluene, o-, m-, and p-xylene) tend to induce the formation of coordination complexes (1, 3, 4, and 8), whereas more polar templates (nitrobenzene, methylsalicylate) display the formation of coordination polymers (2 and 5-7) with only one exception wherein the less polar template o-xylene gives rise to both coordination polymer (2) and coordination complex (1) in the same pot. Atthough 1, 3, and 4 are coordination complexes displaying pseudo-supramolecular isomerism due to different ligand conformation and solvate contents, the coordination polymers 2 and 5 are best described as pseudo-polymorphs in coordination polymer displaying remarkably similar supramolecular architectures despite having identical coordination spheres and ligand conformation (syn-syn). The effect of positional isomerism of 3bpu and 4bpu can be seen in the coordination polymers 6 and 7, wherein both the polymers display near identical coordination sphere having grid type of architectures. Although the space within the grid is blocked because of syn-syn conformation of 3bpu in 6, 3-fold interpenetration is observed in 7 presumably to prevent the collapse of the large grid. This contribution clearly demonstrates how important the role of solvents, conformational flexibility, and positional isomerism of the hydrogen-bond-functionalized ligands is in determining the final products and various isomerisms of the coordinative metal-organic systems.

elements.content: Materials and Measurements. Syntheses and characterization of ligands 3bpu and 4bpu were previously reported by our group. All other chemicals were commercially available (Aldrich) and used without further purification. FT-IR spectra were recorded using Perkin-Elmer Spectrum GX and TGA analyses were performed on a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA851e. Powder X-ray patterns were recorded on XPERT Philips (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.5418 Å) diffractometer.

Experimental Section

 Materials and Measurements. Syntheses and characterization of ligands 3bpu and 4bpu were previously reported by our group. All other chemicals were commercially available (Aldrich) and used without further purification. FT-IR spectra were recorded using Perkin-Elmer Spectrum GX and TGA analyses were performed on a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA851e. Powder X-ray patterns were recorded on XPERT Philips (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.5418 Å) diffractometer.

elements.content: Syntheses of Coordination Polymers. [{(H 2 O) 2 Cd(3bpu) 4 }·(NO 3 ) 2 ·2H 2 O·X] 1. Coordination complex 1 was synthesized by layering a methanolic solution (10 mL) of Cd(NO3)2·6H2O (61.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) over a solution of 3bpu (85.6 mg, 0.4 mmol) in toluene:MeOH (1:1, v/v, 10 mL). After a period of 1 week, X-ray quality single crystals were obtained (48.7 mg, 0.04 mmol) Yield:  20%. Anal. Calcd for C44H44CdN18O12·2MeOH·6H2O:  C, 42.45; H, 4.96; N, 19.37. Found:  C, 42.78; H, 4.86; N, 19.61; the assigned composition as per single-crystal data is [{(H2O)2Cd(3bpu) 4}·(NO3)2〈2H2O·X]. However, analytical data matches with the composition [{(H2O)2Cd(3bpu)4}·(NO3)2·2H2O·2MeOH·4H2O], meaning that the disordered component could be MeOH and water, which is also in accordance with TGA (Table ) and SQUEEZE calculations. FT-IR (cm-1):  3319 w, 3279 m, 3133 w, 3084 m, 2369 w, 1708 vs, 1590 m, 1557 vs, 1485 s, 1427 vs, 1383 m, 1339 b, 1269 s, 1209 b, 1131 w, 1056 b, 1031 b, 903 s, 810 vs, 703 vs, 637 s, 511 w, 413 m.

elements.content: Single -Crystal X-ray Diffraction. X-ray single-crystal data were collected using Mo Kα (λ = 0.7107 Å) radiation on a SMART APEX diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector. Data collection, data reduction, and structure solution/refinement were carried out using the software package of SMART APEX. Graphics were generated using MERCURY 1.4.
elements.clean_text: Single -Crystal  X-ray Diffraction. X-ray single-crystal data were collected using Mo Kα (λ = 0.7107 Å) radiation on a SMART APEX diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector. Data collection, data reduction, and structure solution/refinement were carried out using the  software package of SMART APEX. Graphics were generated using MERCURY 1.4.

elements.content: All structures were solved by direct methods and refined in a routine manner. In all cases, non-hydrogen atoms were treated anisotropically. Whenever possible, the hydrogen atoms were located on a difference Fourier map and refined. In other cases, the hydrogen atoms were geometrically fixed.
elements.clean_text: All structures were solved by direct methods and refined in a routine manner. In all cases, non-hydrogen atoms were treated anisotropically. Whenever possible, the hydrogen atoms were located on a difference Fourier map and refined. In other cases, the hydrogen atoms were geometrically fixed.

elements.content: In 2, the statistically disordered o-xylene was refined anisotropically keeping SOF of two of the carbon atoms (C29 and C30) at 0.5. In 7, the oxygen atoms of the disordered nitrate anion were refined using the second variable facility (FVAR) provided with SHELXTL.
elements.clean_text: In 2, the statistically disordered o-xylene was refined anisotropically keeping SOF of two of the carbon atoms (C29 and C30) at 0.5. In 7, the oxygen atoms of the disordered nitrate anion were refined using the second variable facility (FVAR) provided with SHELXTL.

elements.content: In the cases of 1, 2, and 5, the contribution of the disordered guests molecules to the diffraction pattern was subtracted from the observed data using a “bypass” technique known as SQUEEZE. With these “noise-free” data and relatively less refinable parameters, it was then possible to carry out further refinement of the structures, which converged to significantly low R values.

With these "noise-free" data and relatively less refinable parameters, it was then possible to carry out further refinement of the structures, which converged to significantly low R values.

cln_elements.content:
Syntheses of Coordination Polymers. [{(H 2 O) 2 Cd(3bpu) 4 }·(NO 3 ) 2 ·2H 2 O·X] 1. Coordination complex 1 was synthesized by layering a methanolic solution (10 mL) of Cd(NO3)2·6H2O (61.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) over a solution of 3bpu (85.6 mg, 0.4 mmol) in toluene:MeOH (1:1, v/v, 10 mL). After a period of 1 week, X-ray quality single crystals were obtained (48.7 mg, 0.04 mmol) Yield:  20%. Anal. Calcd for C44H44CdN18O12·2MeOH·6H2O:  C, 42.45; H, 4.96; N, 19.37. Found:  C, 42.78; H, 4.86; N, 19.61; the assigned composition as per single-crystal data is [{(H2O)2Cd(3bpu) 4}·(NO3)2〈2H2O·X]. However, analytical data matches with the composition [{(H2O)2Cd(3bpu)4}·(NO3)2·2H2O·2MeOH·4H2O], meaning that the disordered component could be MeOH and water, which is also in accordance with TGA (Table ) and SQUEEZE calculations. FT-IR (cm-1):  3319 w, 3279 m, 3133 w, 3084 m, 2369 w, 1708 vs, 1590 m, 1557 vs, 1485 s, 1427 vs, 1383 m, 1339 b, 1269 s, 1209 b, 1131 w, 1056 b, 1031 b, 903 s, 810 vs, 703 vs, 637 s, 511 w, 413 m.

[{(H 2 O) 3 (NO 3 )Cd( μ -3bpu)}·(NO 3 )·H 2 O·1/2 o -xylene] n 2. Coordination polymer 2 was synthesized by layering a methanolic solution (10 mL) of Cd(NO3)2·6H2O (61.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) over a solution of 3bpu in o-xylene:MeOH (85.6 mg, 0.4 mmol) (1:1, v/v, 10 mL). After a period of 1 week, needle-shaped X-ray quality single crystals of 2 along with plates were obtained. The plates were found to be complex 1. (35 mg, 0.06 mmol) Yield:  30%. Anal. Calcd for C11H16CdN6O10·H2O:  C, 25.28; H, 3.47; N, 16.08. Found:  C, 25.21; H, 4.32; N, 15.78; the composition of compound 2 appears to be [{(H2O)3(NO3)Cd(μ-3bpu)}·(NO3)·H2O] n instead of [{(H2O)3(NO3)Cd(μ-3bpu)}·(NO3)·H2O·1/2o-xylene] n as assigned from single-crystal data. The absence of 1/2 o-xylene is not surprising considering its disordered nature in the crystal. FT-IR (cm-1):  3438 b, 3282 m, 3145 w, 3094 m, 2926 m, 2375 w, 1709 vs, 1656 m, 1590 vs, 1564 vs, 1482 vs, 1431 vs, 1383 vs, 1361 b, 1277 s, 1229 m, 1133 m, 1069 m, 911 m, 805 vs, 750 s, 698 s, 643 s.

cln_elements.content: [{(H 2 O) 3 (NO 3 )Cd( μ -3bpu)}.(NO 3 ).X] n 5. Crystals of 5 belongs to the centrosymmetric orthorhombic space group Pbcn. The asymmetric unit is comprised of one 3bpu, three water molecules, one nitrate, all coordinated to the metal center Cd(II), one nitrate as counteranion, and some disordered electron density peaks (1.27−1.97 e/Å3) that could not be accounted for. In the final cycle of refinement, the unaccounted electron densities are squeezed out17 and only the ordered components are refined. The metal center displays hepta-coordinated and slightly distorted octahedral geometry (∠O−Cd−O = 73.0(2)−83.2(2)°; ∠N−Cd−N = 177.9(2)°); the apical positions are occupied by the N atoms of the 3bpu ligands and the equatorial positions are coordinated by the three water molecules and the nitrate counteranion, which coordinates to the metal center in a chelate fashion resulting in hepta-coordination.
